answer_html: And all of these are true since \(\displaystyle 1728 = 2^{6}3^{3}\).Hence 1729 is a Carmichael number.
answer_latex:
And all of these are true since
$\displaystyle 1728 = 2^{6}3^{3}$.Hence 1729 is a Carmichael
number.
hints_html:
A Carmichael number is a composite number n which satisfies

\(\displaystyle b^{n-1} \equiv 1 \mod{n}\)

for all integers with \(\displaystyle \gcd(b,n) = 1\).

Recall Korselt’s criterion which states that a positive composite integer n is a Carmichael number if and only if n is square free and for all prime divisors p of n, it is true that \(\displaystyle (p-1) \mid (n-1)\)
hints_latex:
A Carmichael number is a composite number \emph{n} which satisfies

$\displaystyle b^{n-1} \equiv 1 \mod{n}$

for all integers with $\displaystyle \gcd(b,n) = 1$.

Recall Korselt's criterion which states that a positive composite
integer \emph{n} is a Carmichael number if and only if \emph{n} is
square free and for all prime divisors \emph{p} of \emph{n}, it is true
that $\displaystyle (p-1) \mid (n-1)$
hints_raw:
A Carmichael number is a composite number ''n'' which satisfies 

<math> \displaystyle b^{n-1} \equiv 1 \mod{n}</math>

for all integers with <math> \displaystyle \gcd(b,n) = 1</math>.
Recall Korselt's criterion which states that a positive composite integer ''n'' is a Carmichael number if and only if ''n'' is square free and for all prime divisors ''p'' of ''n'', it is true that <math> \displaystyle (p-1) \mid (n-1)</math>
question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
We proceed using the hints. Clearly 1729 is square free so it suffices to check that for each prime divisor, we have that \((p-1)\mid(n-1)\). We proceed mechanically

\[\begin{aligned} (7-1) &= 6 \mid 1728 \\ (13-1) &= 12 \mid 1728 \\ (19-1) &= 18 \mid 1728 \end{aligned}\]

And all of these are true since \(\displaystyle 1728 = 12^{3} = 2^{6}3^{3}\). Hence 1729 is a Carmichael number.
sols_latex:

(13-1) &= 12 \mid 1728 \\
(19-1) &= 18 \mid 1728 
\end{align*}

And all of these are true since
$\displaystyle 1728 = 12^{3} = 2^{6}3^{3}$. Hence 1729 is a Carmichael
number.
sols_raw:
We proceed using the hints. Clearly 1729 is square free so it suffices to check that for each prime divisor, we have that <math>(p-1)\mid(n-1) </math>. We proceed mechanically

<math>
\begin{align}
(7-1) &= 6 \mid 1728 \\
(13-1) &= 12 \mid 1728 \\
(19-1) &= 18 \mid 1728 
\end{align}
</math>

And all of these are true since <math> \displaystyle 1728 = 12^{3} = 2^{6}3^{3}</math>. Hence 1729 is a Carmichael number.
statement_html:
Prove that \(\displaystyle 1729 = 7 \cdot 13 \cdot 19\) is a Carmichael number.

(Hint

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 1728 = 6 \cdot 288 = 12 \cdot 144 = 18 \cdot 96\end{aligned}\]

)

\end{align*})
statement_raw:
Prove that <math> \displaystyle 1729 = 7 \cdot 13 \cdot 19</math> is a Carmichael number. 

(Hint: <math> \displaystyle 1728 = 6 \cdot 288 = 12 \cdot 144 = 18 \cdot 96</math>)
